case_vignette:
A 73-year-old man comes in to the emergency department because of nausea and severe pain in his upper abdomen and right shoulder blade for the past day. He was able to eat a little for breakfast but vomited up the meal a couple of hours later. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years and drinks 4 beers every week. He appears acutely distressed. His temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 124/min, and blood pressure is 92/68 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation of the right upper quadrant with soft crepitus. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 14.3 g/dL
Leukocyte count 18,100/mm3
Platelet count 216,000/mm3
Serum
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, SGOT) 41 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, SGPT) 19 U/L
Alkaline phosphatase 110 U/L
Total bilirubin 0.9 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin 0.2 mg/dL
Albumin 4.1 g/dL
Ultrasonography of the right upper quadrant shows a gallbladder with an air-filled, thickened wall and no stones in the lumen.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?"

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Gastrointestinal System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been feeling nauseous and have severe pain in my upper belly area and right shoulder blade since yesterday.
Have you had any vomiting or changes in your bowel movements since the pain started?
Yes, I vomited my breakfast a couple of hours after eating it.
Have you ever had this type of pain before, or is this the first time?
This is the first time I'm experiencing this type of pain.
Do you have any other symptoms such as fever, jaundice, or changes in the color of your urine or stool?
I feel like I might have a fever, but I haven't noticed any changes in the color of my urine or stool.
Have you experienced any recent trauma to your abdomen or been involved in any strenuous activities?
No, I haven't had any trauma to my abdomen or done any strenuous activities.
Do you have any history of gallbladder issues or gallstones in your family?
I'm not sure about my family history, but I haven't had any gallbladder issues myself before.
Do you have any pre-existing conditions or are you currently taking any medications?
I have type 2 diabetes and I take metformin for it.
Are you currently experiencing any changes in appetite or significant weight loss without trying?
I was able to eat a little for breakfast, but that's all I can say about my appetite right now.
Are you experiencing any shortness of breath, heart palpitations, or dizziness along with your other symptoms?
No, I'm not experiencing shortness of breath, heart palpitations, or dizziness.
How old are you and what is your sex?
I am a 73-year-old man.
**Final Diagnosis:** Acute cholecystitis (inflammation of the gallbladder).

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A 73-year-old man comes into the clinic complaining of severe pain in his upper belly area and right shoulder blade, along with nausea. He vomited his breakfast a couple of hours after eating it and feels like he might have a fever. He denies any changes in the color of his urine or stool, and also denies any recent trauma to his abdomen or strenuous activities. He reports having type 2 diabetes and taking metformin for it. He was able to eat a little for breakfast and denies shortness of breath, heart palpitations, or dizziness.
